mentions.context: CLEAN: 7K clean sentences with their modified extractions.

OpenIE6 (Kolluru et al., 2020a) is a neural model that achieves state-of-theart results when compared with several other models (Del Corro and Gemulla, 2013;Gashteovski et al., 2017;Cui et al., 2018;Stanovsky et al., 2018;Roy et al., 2019;Zhan and Zhao, 2020;Kolluru et al., 2020b).
OpenIE6 (Kolluru et al., 2020a) receives in input a sentence and outputs a list of extractions of the form ⟨subject, predicate, object⟩.
OpenIE6 has been evaluated on the CaRB dataset (Bhardwaj et al., 2019).
OpenIE6.
OpenIE6(ECIN).
OpenIE6(ECIN) improves upon OpenIE6, with a significant increase in the precision of the WiRe57 metric, which is expected given the hard constraints are being forced on the triples.
OpenIE6(ECTR).
OpenIE6 model with entity constraint training (ECTR), as in Section 4.

PostprocessedOpenIE6. We run the original OpenIE6 tool and post-process its output as follows: we tag entities in subject and object of the extractions, and then we modify extractions, in the same manner as when we created the CLEAN dataset (Section 5.1), and leave unchanged the ones not satisfying our conditions.

The OpenIE6 dataset consists of Wikipedia sentences, while the Pubmed data is a set of conflict of interest statements between authors and various organizations, such as those illustrated in Section 1.
The OpenIE6 training dataset consists of 91K sentences and 190K extractions of the form ⟨subject, predicate, object⟩.

However,OpenIE6(ECTR) has a more significant improvement than OpenIE6(ECIN) according to WiRe57 (the metric aligned with our problem statement, as explained in Section 5.2), showing that it is more important to have soft constraints, which are rewarding good extractions during training and hence obtaining a better extraction model.
• Training OpenIE6 with more constraints requires around 3h/epoch, while the model with the original constraints requires half this time.
We use the OpenIE6 data for training and validation and Pubmed data for testing.
In addition, Ope-nIE6 has shown better performance than models using dependency parsing such as ClausIE (Kolluru et al., 2020a;Del Corro and Gemulla, 2013).
This is the default OpenIE6 model.
To the trained model OpenIE6, we add constraints at inference in the evaluation of the test data.

Regarding the baselines, PostprocessedOpenIE6 and FilteredOpenIE6 have good precision but lower recall than our top-performing models, showing the importance of the constraint learning and adapted training datasets.
OpenIE6(ECIN) improves upon OpenIE6, with a significant increase in the precision of the WiRe57 metric, which is expected given the hard constraints are being forced on the triples.
We analyse the extractions by OpenIE6(ECTR) and the original OpenIE6 model on a larger PubMed dataset consisting of 170K sentences.
We remove the extractions from PostprocessedOpenIE6 that were not modified according to the procedure used for generating the CLEAN dataset.
The conjunctive model is a core OpenIE6 component; gains in its precision would likely improve performance, both with and without constraints.
We deployed our technique within OpenIE6 (Kolluru et al., 2020a), a state-of-the-art tool for OIE.
We note that the results for the OpenIE6 model are slightly lower than those reported in the original paper because of the coordinate boundary model, as mentioned in Section 5.
We take our best performing model, OpenIE6(ECTR) trained on the CLEAN dataset, and we train it with 1, 2, or 3 constraints at a time.

As expected, the models trained on the CLEAN dataset perform the worst, as they have seen only extractions with entities in the arguments; to achieve the best results, the user should choose a model considering the nature of the dataset.
Their full equations can be found in the OpenIE6 paper (Kolluru et al., 2020a).

PostprocessedOpenIE6. We run the original OpenIE6 tool and post-process its output as follows: we tag entities in subject and object of the extractions, and then we modify extractions, in the same manner as when we created the CLEAN dataset (Section 5.1), and leave unchanged the ones not satisfying our conditions.
• Users trying our tool, but also the original OpenIE model, should have the computational possibility of using the BERT-based model, the main component of OpenIE6.

Our salient contributions are: i) We extend the OpenIE6 model with entity-centric constraints; ii) We implement the constraints as penalties in the loss function, and as hard constraints during inference.
where λ * are hyperparameters, while J is the original OpenIE6 loss.
We retrained the coordinate boundary model using a newer Huggingface Transformers library version (Wolf et al., 2020) for compatibility with our code.
Combining soft and hard constraints gives the best model, OpenIE6(ECTR, ECIN).

However, we show that the constrained models trained on the MIXED and ORIGINAL datasets have competitive performance with the original OpenIE6 model while performing much better on our test data, as shown in Table 2.
We analyse the extractions by OpenIE6(ECTR) and the original OpenIE6 model on a larger PubMed dataset consisting of 170K sentences.

However,OpenIE6(ECTR) has a more significant improvement than OpenIE6(ECIN) according to WiRe57 (the metric aligned with our problem statement, as explained in Section 5.2), showing that it is more important to have soft constraints, which are rewarding good extractions during training and hence obtaining a better extraction model.

Finally, when comparing the model with no entity constraints, OpenIE6, with the model enforcing all 4 constraints, OpenIE6(ECTR), we observe a more significant difference in the violations ENT-ARG and ENT-REL, the constraints that are more frequently violated.
We take our best performing model, OpenIE6(ECTR) trained on the CLEAN dataset, and we train it with 1, 2, or 3 constraints at a time.
1. We first use the coordinate boundary detection model (available with OpenIE6 code).
Several evaluation metrics have been proposed to evaluate the performance of an OpenIE system.
We note that the models use a different coordinate boundary model than the one in the OpenIE6 paper.
We add the remaining sentences and their extractions from the original training set to CLEAN.
We tag entities in each sentence using the state-ofthe-art named entity recognition tool Flair (Akbik et al., 2019).
In addition, adding entity constraints further improves the results as shown by the models OpenIE6(ECTR) which has the best WiRe57 score for all CLEAN, MIXED and ORIG-INAL models.
In addition, Ope-nIE6 has shown better performance than models using dependency parsing such as ClausIE (Kolluru et al., 2020a;Del Corro and Gemulla, 2013).

Finally, when comparing the model with no entity constraints, OpenIE6, with the model enforcing all 4 constraints, OpenIE6(ECTR), we observe a more significant difference in the violations ENT-ARG and ENT-REL, the constraints that are more frequently violated.

When training without any entity constraints, the training dataset can make a significant difference, as we observe OpenIE6 trained on CLEAN has a more than 26% increase in CaRB F1 than OpenIE6 trained on the ORIGINAL dataset.
We remove the extractions from PostprocessedOpenIE6 that were not modified according to the procedure used for generating the CLEAN dataset.

When training without any entity constraints, the training dataset can make a significant difference, as we observe OpenIE6 trained on CLEAN has a more than 26% increase in CaRB F1 than OpenIE6 trained on the ORIGINAL dataset.

However, we show that the constrained models trained on the MIXED and ORIGINAL datasets have competitive performance with the original OpenIE6 model while performing much better on our test data, as shown in Table 2.
In addition, adding entity constraints further improves the results as shown by the models OpenIE6(ECTR) which has the best WiRe57 score for all CLEAN, MIXED and ORIG-INAL models.

PostprocessedOpenIE6. We run the original OpenIE6 tool and post-process its output as follows: we tag entities in subject and object of the extractions, and then we modify extractions, in the same manner as when we created the CLEAN dataset (Section 5.1), and leave unchanged the ones not satisfying our conditions.

While some approaches (Yao et al., 2011;Yu et al., 2017) extract surface forms of relations when the arguments are entities, similar to our goal in this work, they use for this only dependency path information and do not deal with conjunctive sentences as OpenIE (Kolluru et al., 2020a).
